CCD46A910E6844188F784F46FAEEFC52.description: Examine the importance of scientific ethics in investigations.

E73E07E76DBD44A99699FAAE7CF637A0.description: Discuss potential impacts of evidence that is not communicated clearly and accurately.

9CA80928B4234616ACFE6BFA2485952C.description: Compare the clarity and accuracy of evidence communicated by diverse representations of data.

E92CC50312E64EDFA9A29E411611B6DB.description: Discuss the use of diverse representations of data in communicating evidence.

116C629B4C8B45CDADAAD715C515F3AD.description: Defend a conclusion about cause and effect based on evidence produced in a controlled experiment.

83B3A40797F7492FA35FF6A35240787B.description: Evaluate the effect of the manipulated variable on the responding variable in a controlled experiment.

61AD37AE27BA435EB05110AA36A63481.description: Apply vocabulary for variables correctly in science contexts.

6E2E10F9A6454E578148F864406C3DFC.description: Identify the variables in a controlled experiment.

3B4B7F92F46F4A2D96C06AA89164C12F.description: Plan and conduct a controlled experiment.

9AC57C17D35F429A9502AD927E214C80.description: Identify biases that could influence an investigation.

F2D5C78AC7734415A97A50339E49418E.description: Discuss technologies that provide scientists with evidence that cannot be directly observed using the human senses.

6DCE7532E0DD442C8F62E68F9D436BD5.description: Evidence needs to be produced, handled, and shared ethically.

1DE36A3658A543778794E21C1C648693.description: Evidence must be communicated clearly and accurately.

07DB11F8568A4024A65B73A694B023DE.description: Evidence from a controlled experiment can be used to make conclusions about cause-and-effect relationships between variables.

A45FEF6602D748A3B59DC7AC19A35525.description: Evidence is more reliable and valid when investigations are conducted in a way that limits bias.

1CDCA257DA8848EAB4FF97F70138C879.description: Investigations can be conducted to better understand phenomena.

EE4B607F5DCB47CAA41F3B266C2B9FCC.description: Scientific ethics are demonstrated during investigations in ways such as not changing data in an experiment, minimizing harm to environments, humans, and other animals, respecting the privacy of participants b and limiting personal bias

62D85C2B21F74A0FB272B3EC565A7C17.description: Scientific ethics are principles and rules that guide behaviour when conducting scientific investigations.

A1239D8A5B5147D29ED6CABDB007465C.description: Evidence that is not communicated clearly and accurately can influence the validity and reliability of the investigation.

FD0463E8C4264072AEE067DB197674B4.description: Evidence that is communicated clearly and accurately uses correct vocabulary, includes all relevant data, is free from personal bias and can be understood by the intended audience

5665B14322FE48278C450870CF371C5D.description: Diverse representations of data can communicate evidence differently.

AA8360303E7B440A843A4595BA7BA520.description: Representations of data can include all or some of the data.

58A326F675CB45A98F7E7EBBF49FEFE6.description: A controlled experiment is an investigation in which one variable is changed and all other variables are kept the

204B79179C14498999B39CB1C407B956.description: A controlled variable is kept the same in a controlled experiment.

80A45A059236461EAAEFFC976FB851CF.description: A responding or dependent variable changes as a result of changes to the manipulated variable in a controlled experiment.

A22D0600E33848DBAF85CB9FF3F71CEF.description: A manipulated or independent variable is changed to determine what effect the change will have on the responding variable in a controlled experiment.

FDDC54CF5DAB4A44AC92B06E5F4C5AD5.description: A variable is a condition or factor that can influence the outcome of an experiment.

580D6DB6AFFC4C2DB5D42AA7E4B33492.description: Humans are not usually aware of their personal biases.

167B34BF3CCB43BEAF0A0B599E125071.description: Bias is any personal thoughts, feelings, or expectations that influence an investigation.

EA3CEF38040F405EA4FDF8522BACB802.description: Natural phenomena occur without human input, such as lightning and auroras.

833F31FF4B994BF19EF2B62797FC4E6C.description: Phenomena that cannot be directly observed using the human senses can be observed and measured using technologies such as telescopes, microscopes, and X-rays.

135D92E3547146F0AA3246EE34DC0DCB.description: Some phenomena can be directly observed using the human senses.

78A591C715F849438A5B33A7B9B762E9.description: Phenomena are facts or events that can be observed.

636741D55F2B4D3E9E48719138950951.description: Students investigate how evidence is gathered and explain the importance of ethics in science.

1CA769506D7942138F0848D294A13952.description: Scientific Methods: Investigation of the physical world is enhanced through the use of scientific methods that attempt to remove human biases and increase objectivity.

9F791705A64F4A459D76591CBAF4AC6B.description: Develop multiple iterations of an artifact.

7BF6F1AE0556471D91AA3D1ED86C35EC.description: Propose enhancements and refinements to an artifact in collaboration with others.

047C908CB932427D8A90F0C6AD33DB67.description: Design an artifact to meet a need.

FC0C1BB1A49B400CAB9072EC715A2CB0.description: Evaluate an artifact based on various factors.

E444C9EB3B6844F4BDACC09A47A66A40.description: Discuss examples of designs that have been enhanced or refined to better meet needs.

0F079410A77C42B48F78A2D5E5C119B7.description: Design an algorithm that includes a loop and translate it into code.

775BF3BDFAEB47E7AA61E2B95B6E911C.description: Translate a given algorithm to code using a visual block-based language.

90D5EFB6EA874775A13EE039EBCF83D5.description: Explain what will happen when single or multiple blocks of code are executed.

C05F76902D094F779C7EE643459BDE40.description: Relate a block of code to an outcome or a behaviour.

F78B590B7ED3491CBD41152537ECC9B9.description: Engage in the design process to create computational artifacts.

33346B0A7FA247CE9B154A1D1B017251.description: Design can better meet needs through the development of multiple iterations.

31C1962112C048799088AF8AFC602E5F.description: Design can be used by humans or machines to meet needs.

AE3F8B87DF1B4B0E881411ECC00C3891.description: Design can be improved through collaboration.

5CADBDE9306A4A46A6236CC7074FD19C.description: Design processes that support the development of multiple iterations include enhancing and refining

A6062559301D421FBA8367EFDFC93E1A.description: Usability is the degree of ease with which something can be used to achieve an outcome.

56E7919D654748C8845ABDF907324AD7.description: Functionality is the quality of being useful to do the job for which something was designed.

93F495CA8B7E4C809710B355501BAFF8.description: Design process can be influenced by various factors, including safety, functionality, usability, reliability, efficiency and aesthetics

88ED4092F449487DA484ADAC59AE4231.description: A loop is a repetition of instructions used in an algorithm.

33268CD475574EF696288B636AFCA100.description: A computer cannot think for itself and must rely on code for all that it does.

AB136D22F5ED4B02AC760D36409BE1AF.description: Visual block-based languages are a form of code in which prepared chunks of instructions are in drag-and-drop blocks that fit together like puzzle pieces to design a program.

B23E40E222874BCDB7DB8C8CA1ECA71C.description: There are many ways to code, including using visual block-based languages.

15B1989ACA944B7AA0A967E6E563209F.description: Code is any language that can be understood by and run on a computer.

8F44DB5CAB1245AA9A1E3E6AFB3FE876.description: Design can be used to create algorithms and translate them into code.

70153C7C4F7948FB8B886917C5EAED20.description: A computational artifact is anything created by a human using a computer, such as computer programs and code images audio, video, presentations and web pages

BB4322BF2D7645CFBD65E3C7BCB3FD39.description: Students apply design processes when creating artifacts that can be used by a human or machine to address a need.

2424C8EE01234E57B927A2B5E10C3A61.description: Computer Science: Problem solving and scientific inquiry are developed through the knowledgeable application of creativity, design, and computational thinking.

B41CA0D2EFEC4312BFFACE31E6F1DB54.description: Identify how observation of astronomical phenomena can determine agricultural and hunting practices.

058F5FB4672B4840B8517831C22FDAD1.description: Explore Indigenous representations of astronomical phenomena, past and present.

0E150A2868EA4304B147CD0F72D3F9E1.description: Represent astronomical phenomena in a variety of ways.

22F273B0D65F4728A834903ADCD6498C.description: Explore Inuit, northern First Nations’, or Métis’ stories related to the midnight sun, the polar night, or the northern lights.

58F8F40175704C008AE4226F24344E64.description: Explore First Nations, Métis, and Inuit understandings of phases and cycles within astronomical phenomena that inform ways of living and community activities.

60082BBB5A904ED7B7C9B0233B136EEB.description: Identify astronomical phenomena that occur cyclically.

218646457BD540C597045122A096F8F3.description: Discuss observable features of lunar and solar eclipses and auroras.

39240B6981204A1CBB91EC34DAEAA1E4.description: Describe personal observations related to cyclical changes in the Moon's appearance.

9D6579E4444241E19B555E333D217247.description: Connect the direction of Earth's tilt in relation to the Sun to the length of day and night in each season.

BDB7FBC9B6414D1C98C5BF269583CDCD.description: Observations and interpretations of astronomical phenomena can inform daily living.

A3E9B027B50349DF94EDEDCD414E2750.description: Observations and interpretations of astronomical phenomena can be applied in various contexts, including planting and harvesting crops hunting

E0F1EC6C9D104AD9B84944E433791940.description: Astronomical phenomena can be represented in various ways that connect to daily life, including calendars, cycles, stories and legends, artifacts and models and digital simulations

1CAC4DEFB2B24121BECFB78B5C6E2186.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit ways of living and significant events are connected to many astronomical phenomena, such as the association of seasons to ceremonies.

92D5773C6E5D4711AB21CB712FDB48DB.description: In the northern hemisphere, auroras are referred to as the northern lights (aurora borealis).

DB20F735ACF445CD8AE6520D55C27389.description: Longer and shorter days are experienced during different times of the year in the northern and southern hemispheres of Earth because these regions are tilted toward the Sun at different times of the year.

B71752FEDCCC4A02A7EC3819A085B01B.description: Seasons are experienced during different times of the year in the northern and southern hemispheres of Earth because these regions are tilted toward the Sun at different times of the year.

30911FAFF126418195A6F8F6CC7AF380.description: Astronomical phenomena, such as Moon phases, can have predictable patterns and cycles.

67837EF67EB04B11A2D9675B408613E9.description: Astronomical phenomena include seasons, Moon phases, lunar and solar eclipses, equinoxes and solstices, length of day and night and auroras

69CAD9F9AF994ED0BCB627C3221A6AA2.description: Astronomical phenomena are observable events that happen among objects in space.

6F45FFFF653F4A80B12AAE8969281952.description: Students investigate and interpret astronomical phenomena.

87B1DC9DA9C442A8871243902B4C15F6.description: Space: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

434FD755549D491693793BBEC7980F97.description: Examine the transport systems of plants and describe their functions.

A258A22BC96244E7B14ED54A0D63F827.description: Investigate the relationships between body systems that are involved in moving oxygen and nutrients throughout the human body.

6DBD07C520C449C2958008BBF5FB6101.description: Identify the digestive, respiratory, circulatory, and musculoskeletal systems of the human body and the major body parts of each system.

0C7561CFA6424DEF809A82F677D9FAD7.description: Examine the function of the human digestive, respiratory, circulatory, and musculoskeletal systems.

CE7DE3BC47304F0389C74F3880401834.description: Relate vital biological processes to a human or other animal's internal biological systems.

7B27CC890A684066A6B29F4EF2E3CF11.description: Plants are complex organisms with transport systems that carry out specific functions for survival.

11B618A3DD9647C7A0B78C8E0702EA1E.description: Humans are complex organisms with biological systems that carry out vital biological processes.

624ABFD67E1F46F58A281CBCF9C39A23.description: Phloem transports sugars from the leaves to the rest of the plant.

1800E515A20B41B2AC1FF4F4CF6DACD4.description: Xylem transports water and nutrients from the roots to the rest of the plant.

F88126F9816141D0AA661D4478F702E2.description: Xylem and phloem in plants perform similar functions to the circulatory system in animals.

A7EE15C1F1334F48A49F55327CC7DB67.description: Plant transport systems include xylem and phloem.

D57A9002247A473589330D7551E91C75.description: The digestive, respiratory, and circulatory systems work together to supply oxygen and nutrients to the human body.

ECDFE5428682417398A78107481A1F01.description: The musculoskeletal system supports and moves the body, and includes muscles and bones.

0BF76B15E83F4F2889BA69F39F61DD3B.description: The circulatory system moves blood around the body and includes the heart and blood vessels.

228B5F40F2AF433DB83252B540B04D21.description: The respiratory system exchanges oxygen and carbon dioxide, and includes the trachea, lungs, and diaphragm.

73637F72E2504C0680B22F02C9BE534D.description: The digestive system breaks down food and absorbs nutrients, and includes the mouth, stomach, intestines, liver, and pancreas.

A1B044E752EA4BADA1DC90CEA0FF0D26.description: Humans and many other animals have internal biological systems that include the digestive system, respiratory system, circulatory system and musculoskeletal system

31837F11F5F04615B65CF8808533CD5A.description: Vital biological processes of complex organisms include  movement , nutrition, respiration, growth and reproduction

BFA2E3DFD2DB4AE387009EA448AF002F.description: Vital biological processes in complex organisms are carried out by biological systems that rely on each other.

0DAA8589A04B4A9EB10F7A02E7E0FCD9.description: Students investigate the internal systems of organisms and explain how they support vital biological processes.

79E4E555D41540E1B830850C1476B3F8.description: Living Systems: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

1A39329E1ACC4927B2963D3C198B3E19.description: Examine how weather conditions and animal behaviour can be used to recognize weather patterns and cycles.

3084B2FF0B2C47239D73C0D1B7F5DF70.description: Explain practices related to sustainable harvesting.

010E2359AD3B452EB1C59DC00AF85923.description: Describe local climate and weather events that affect agricultural practices.

2BCCDBF93AFF40A1B50AA1BD588CFD29.description: Discuss conservation agriculture practices and potential uses.

678B40CC72C54597A88BD7E4718E9653.description: Describe how climate may affect plants and animals farmed in Alberta.

3998C185420D4300B757A1A38B4369FF.description: Explain how climate can affect human and other animal activity.

B7CBB1F20BD747B9A3EEB5F3F69E7A8D.description: Discuss First Nations, Métis, and Inuit methods of predicting weather.

28D2F926D4234A73AA57F06052CEE4E3.description: Investigate methods used to predict the weather.

8B158BC455B748D4984A2BE01D536E1F.description: Explain the importance of weather forecasts.

78AF62BF73184E56A4E2A6BBD24BF7C1.description: Construct a sample weather map of a local region for a given time.

775E2DF2DEB7451FAB670BC1AF8FE60C.description: Observe and record local weather for a given time interval.

79F15BA7F08C4039B182893028B4F9F3.description: Construct simple tools to measure weather.

635A31443BDB401C800BDA23920EA7A0.description: Examine tools used to measure and track weather conditions.

9B0D1CC64201409C9A305F352DB274AD.description: Compare Alberta's climate to the climates of other Canadian provinces or territories.

F4C5B9E1ADAF4579BE3F0FF11E80A036.description: Relate factors that contribute to Alberta's climate.

A91BAF217262458B97591C08A5FDE770.description: Compare key characteristics of climate zones.

EA4F9347E99D47B59E8643F45A1102AC.description: Discuss the characteristics of local, national, and global weather conditions to determine climate.

8599C1D7FA99413CA3ECA376467FBDD1.description: Intergenerational observations and accounts of place enable individuals and communities to recognize patterns and cycles related to weather and seasons.

3E8FF1859B7744D5BD4DEE702AF5E48B.description: Climate and weather events influence agricultural practices.

A7E30ED837BC4FE29AC14FB7FFF75F2D.description: Climate affects human and other animal activity.

52D31DC3CD874BCA9D1281BDB94ECE94.description: Weather conditions can be measured accurately using a variety of tools and methods.

53518C0EA646499AA5A29E8EECB3CFBE.description: The study of climates across regions helps identify historical patterns and make predictions.

7DCFF5DC0B1748BF890C415ABD5452D2.description: Observations of weather conditions and animal behaviour can be used to recognize patterns and cycles, such as seasonal migration.

C16CD7E38FD8463198C7B87828BEBD7D.description: Sustainable harvesting practices support the maintenance of stable plant or animal populations over time and include crop rotation, companion planting, limiting hunting and trapping and considering future harvests

BC88E4CC3CA449AF8EBE41ED2296C2B9.description: Conservation agriculture practices include minimizing soil disturbance, maintaining soil cover, using water efficiently and using sustainable harvesting practices

F4C5C8C552D6494988A46BD92D853779.description: Agricultural practices involve monitoring and responding to climate or weather events such as drought, flooding, fires and windstorms

4902028A114A4C3EA0F8EF3B238AB21C.description: Conservation agriculture practices are adapted to the requirements of plants and animals farmed.

43EB58245E2342B88FE4200DC10296B4.description: Conservation agriculture is a sustainable practice that responds to local climate and weather events.

43E0A66DF192488890EFDBF99A0EDB57.description: Climate and weather events may influence agricultural practices by affecting components such as crop type, crop production, animal population, soil quality and water access

0EAF52471CCC4B3793CCABBC8378B568.description: Climate affects various aspects of animal activity, including migration patterns, accessing food and timing of reproduction

52A34F588D4446DBBFC4EEF9E365F65D.description: Climate affects various aspects of human activity, including agriculture, infrastructure, clothing, transportation and recreation

6DCD7549640C49F49ADACC893868E636.description: Methods used to predict weather include computer modelling, historical data, satellite imaging  and First Nations, Métis, and Inuit traditional knowledge

7CEA87457B3141019C84425DCFBB557F.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit communities rely on traditional knowledge, in addition to modern tools and methods, to interpret and predict weather patterns.

4CD912DC297E4503B2EE33CC74EEE021.description: Websites, weather maps, and weather apps provide access to weather information.

91BEE1DCDA7C476CB8138D035BE9EE12.description: Tools to measure and track weather conditions include  thermometers, wind vanes, windsocks, anemometers, barometers, rain or snow gauges  and hygrometers

42187A81A96B49B1976B4FA8F423FB4A.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit can provide long-term observations of climate for local context.

47E4D9B594CF4D7182E1D8D93137A2DF.description: Climate zones are defined areas with distinct climates and include tropical, dry, temperate, polar and continental

14196EC6BE8A45C0A57844C29DF4D260.description: Climates are dependent on factors that include geographical location, landforms, altitude and proximity to bodies of water

83CEEE80F156478F8473D1F2DE887F6A.description: Data in maps, tables, or graphs can be used to represent key characteristics of climate, including temperature, precipitation, humidity and wind

C1DF75E63A4649A083F5DEB2B2EE569A.description: Climate is the long-term weather patterns of a region over a period of at least 30 years.

76E916CF27E9466BABF226A01A3EF0EF.description: Weather is the short-term conditions experienced in a region, including temperature, wind speed and direction, amount of sunlight, precipitation, humidity and cloud cover

AA01DF15721E432FA1ABF7234D2272D2.description: Students analyze climate and connect it to weather conditions and agricultural practices.

C7510DA0679F4B618BAA6BC80D839753.description: Earth Systems: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

86A3CFE8BC7040C199170BACCA910217.description: Examine how various provinces and territories throughout Canada fulfill energy needs.

DEBCD123EF81425CBE9FFF1A3B80FF29.description: Discuss advantages and disadvantages of using renewable and non-renewable energy resources.

95FEBFCAD35346E9B21563C465475B12.description: Discuss advantages and disadvantages of using renewable and non-renewable energy resources.

7C117CC6B813427DBF9E2981E26A6E4F.description: Compare renewable energy resources with non-renewable energy resources.

A735ACB17E3043678D10E4DF67CF901F.description: Humans rely on energy resources to fulfill energy needs.

0A4543E7240345D393A76238963BA780.description: Alberta relies on both renewable and non-renewable energy resources to fulfill energy needs, including fossil fuels, water and hydro, wind and biomass

3898218BC256492CAD9A3AF7A47D9DCB.description: Non-renewable energy resources include nuclear and fossil fuels.

F70111EDF2554C3598975EA674F51CB7.description: Non-renewable energy resources are depleted over time because they will not be naturally replenished for thousands or millions of years.

09A14DD4ABEC439D976235D01A3193A0.description: Renewable energy resources include solar, wind, biomass, geothermal, tidal and water and hydro

D37F90FF3DB84B28BB740F248326546C.description: Renewable energy resources are not depleted over time as they can be naturally replenished if handled responsibly.

CD96A5C580DE4AB898CE6941821AF44B.description: Energy resources are renewable or non-renewable.

37CDD738E42C469F91386EEE64B01EAC.description: Students investigate and analyze various energy resources.

F4BF6B46F88B4B48BA715E8E98CC307B.description: Practise safe and appropriate use of tools, equipment, and materials while constructing a device.

59530464DB624650B606F4A4487286C1.description: Construct a device that can float.

C8A9718CEDF44E1B896237BA05C27D74.description: Conduct controlled experiments to determine if various objects and materials float in different fluids.

D4584975C6F74739A47B8A7F55CF8A1D.description: Relate buoyant force and weight to the tendency to float or sink in water.

344CFACCCEE44A84BF77023BCC7F8021.description: Practise safe and appropriate use of tools, equipment, and materials while constructing a device.

C69078AFD1274AF29AE782876A5C34BA.description: Construct a device that can fly.

43BABB3AC51F430E85EA75350D306A55.description: Describe traditional or modern technologies developed by diverse cultures that reflect understanding of forces that affect flight.

B7A4CDED409C47FD87F9BE1A0BA006E5.description: Observe living things and objects in flight.

1EA6481C429C46DBBC5D588B7330DB13.description: Explain the effects of lift and weight on the flight of living things and objects.

2D70DFC4F3C240B9BB84B7CE79FF60D9.description: Explain the effects of thrust and drag on the flight of living things and objects.

DFA50AC4FDDD4C92AF9F824F850A2EAC.description: Diagram opposing forces that act on living things or objects in flight.

6EAF7C62CEAE4098A600F4DAC9AAE918.description: The relationship between buoyant force and gravity can be used to explain the behaviour of an object in water.

E19997D13C194B0A8BC618137342DDD2.description: Flight of living things and objects is influenced by opposing forces.

FC64831696524EE68CEEBE2DD88D1A65.description: When the buoyant force is less than the weight of an object, the object will sink.

67D4EC4BBD4448228451D15BB032E6A0.description: When the buoyant force is greater than the weight of an object, the object will float.

2D8ED0E6CF654612BF45863F0EA2318B.description: Buoyant force is an upward force exerted by a fluid that opposes the weight of anything placed in the fluid.

0BC581348EC943BFB4633D68A403F8EF.description: Traditional technologies developed by diverse cultures that reflect understanding of forces that affect flight include the bow and arrow, slingshot and fishing spear

304BBCFE0C294A189952CE8D3C7E907B.description: Forces can affect the flight of living things and objects in various ways, including speed, horizontal and vertical movement, altitude and straight and level flight

79ED2D11FF084AEDBD529AE59551F386.description: Weight is a force caused by gravity that acts on a living thing or object in a downward direction.

C9539F61BC7A4B45B5CE83FA6DA3E28B.description: Lift is an upward force that acts to overcome the weight of a living thing or object and hold it in the air.

F93CE5896D67446EA984DFD3760C1B1C.description: Drag is a force that can act in opposition to the direction of movement.

47B8B15BFB0D4BF5B9EFDE44AB713597.description: Thrust is a force that can act in the direction of movement.

8AA343BE427C48B7B2B37293E208C0D3.description: Lift and weight are opposing forces.

C0E2DB1951DF49B886A1A8A03A74C164.description: Thrust and drag are opposing forces.

4637A17E601D46ABBC2BEB78C22D1B0C.description: Students investigate and compare how forces affect living things and objects in water and air.

9E395D912DCE4986A15C0DECBF13DC8C.description: Energy: Understandings of the physical world are deepened by investigating matter and energy.

330BBBC2171B4EFFAD69F3CD8500041B.description: Practise safe and appropriate use of materials, tools, and equipment.

603AC8D2536A43C7B7F9F641A0C1293E.description: Compare the compressibility of air and water.

375B0BE1807941E39AB07E168E49C578.description: Relate densities of solids, liquids, and gases using the particle model of matter.

FD7603D9DB6849B7822FA6402674A08E.description: Directly compare the density of liquids.

4D64CDE7F7EF408EB446B33927EB72A5.description: Directly compare the density of solid objects that have the same volume.

9CAA77589DB249B98AF877B3BD0BEB28.description: Measure the volume of liquids using appropriate instruments and SI units.

1D68B6FC7C0049BA9003F0AD6B576A24.description: Measure the mass of solids and liquids using a balance scale and SI units.

CD3B581EAC624EA48957E1458FF692B2.description: The movement and arrangement of particles affect the physical properties of matter.

1E32ECE799C947A79C0228A3DAC82EE8.description: The particle model of matter explains the behaviour of particles in matter.

08DFA83101F64BA8BE9AD3175D9581B0.description: Compressibility is the ability of a liquid or gas to reduce in volume when under pressure.

B24890C817CA4BB7852CC2F9C0E98FE1.description: A solid, liquid, or gas that is less dense than the fluid in which it is placed will float.

99934E47F69E4953BD69EA3DA5F0522F.description: Density can be directly compared by determining the relative mass of objects with the same volume if a liquid sinks or floats when added to another liquid

CC57562EE07F4176892F8C0C720E7D03.description: Density can be described comparatively using the phrases denser and less dense.

BBECD819AED742229E64755EBF48E4EA.description: The greater the mass of a solid, liquid, or gas as compared to its volume, the higher its density.

BF89C6DAD3AC43A18B4A31B0D8F5BDA2.description: Density is a comparison of the mass of a solid, liquid, or gas to its volume.

708D3A468E9F440B86C87A29E8E5209C.description: SI units are abbreviated for convenience, including g: grams, kg: kilograms, mL: millilitres and L: litres

E083DD3D683444E8A58F2E3D8ABBB706.description: SI units of volume of a liquid include millilitres and litres.

D80F27B1312F4142AD3C3448F35AF59B.description: Volume is the amount of space a solid, liquid, or gas takes up.

AD4933604E064436BC5A7C23A909D2E4.description: SI units of mass include grams and kilograms.

66647F981FF543B5829D24325ADF36D3.description: Mass is the amount of matter in a solid, liquid, or gas.

800E9A0065DA47CEA6159FA77CE7F986.description: Physical properties of matter include state, mass, volume, density and compressibility

0C79E008B9E54625A391908114554897.description: Attractive forces between particles are strongest in solids and weakest in gases.

3378D39A0FAD44958DA75D8902510D18.description: In gases, the particles are separated by large spaces and are constantly moving in all directions.

A0955416ECE14D6C90A78CEC76F1EB73.description: In liquids, the particles are separated by spaces and can slide past each other.

EA86E6D2811B4F2F8D5ACD1D70556263.description: In solids, the particles are close together and vibrate in place.

89F6E96E3E9E42F9AF954CF54D84D66E.description: Ideas represented by the particle model of matter include that: all matter is made up of small particles, particles of matter are always moving and particles of matter have spaces between them

C356F15B0A204274BE6126576F1642E2.description: Students investigate the particle model of matter in relation to the physical properties of solids, liquids, and gases.

3937405953EA47E2A40DB34DDCDB19A4.description: Matter: Understandings of the physical world are deepened by investigating matter and energy.
